title: Mordecai's Exaltation
shortSummary: Esther Chapter 10 concludes the book by highlighting King Ahasuerus' reign and the exaltation of Mordecai, who is honored as a leader among the Jews and a trusted official of the king. The chapter affirms God's providential care in delivering His people and establishes the lasting celebration of their salvation.
timeline: c. 5th century BC - Persian Empire under King Ahasuerus

keyCharacters.name: King Ahasuerus
keyCharacters.description: The Persian king who rules over a vast empire and honors Mordecai for his loyalty and service.

keyCharacters.name: Mordecai
keyCharacters.description: A Jewish leader elevated to a high position next to the king, recognized for his faithfulness and care for his people.

keyCharacters.name: Esther
keyCharacters.description: The Jewish queen married to King Ahasuerus, through whom God’s deliverance of the Jews was accomplished.

keyCharacters.name: Aman (Haman)
keyCharacters.description: The adversary of the Jews, symbolized as one of the 'two dragons' opposing God's people.

definitions.definition: A tax or payment imposed by a ruler on the land or peoples under his control.

definitions.term: Chronicles of the kings of Media and Persia
definitions.definition: Official historical records maintained by the Persian empire documenting the reigns and deeds of its kings.

outline.heading: King Ahasuerus’ Tribute and Mordecai’s Promotion
outline.description: The chapter opens by noting the king’s imposition of tribute and recounts Mordecai’s exaltation to a position second only to the king, emphasizing his influence among the Jews and his dedication to their welfare.

outline.heading: Mordecai’s Testimony of God’s Providence
outline.description: Mordecai acknowledges God’s hand in the events that transpired, recalling a dream that symbolically represents the conflict between himself and Haman, affirming divine sovereignty over the deliverance of Israel.

outline.heading: God’s Deliverance and the Establishment of Purim
outline.description: The chapter concludes by celebrating God’s salvation of Israel from their enemies, the division of peoples by lots, and the institution of the joyous festival in the month of Adar to commemorate this deliverance forever.

application: Trust in God’s providence even when circumstances seem uncertain, knowing He works all things for His people’s good.
Recognize the importance of faithful leadership that seeks the welfare of God’s people and promotes peace.
Celebrate and remember God’s deliverance through worship and communal rejoicing as a testimony to future generations.
Stand firm against opposition by relying on God’s power and justice rather than human strength.

keyVerses.text: For Mordecai the Jew was next unto king Ahasuerus, and great among the Jews, and accepted of the multitude of his brethren, seeking the wealth of his people, and speaking peace to all his seed.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Mordecai’s honored position and his godly leadership in seeking the good of his people.

keyVerses.text: Then Mardocheus said, God hath done these things.
keyVerses.significance: A clear acknowledgment of God’s sovereign hand in the deliverance and exaltation recorded in the book.

keyVerses.text: Therefore those days shall be unto them in the month Adar, the fourteenth and fifteenth day of the same month, with an assembly, and joy, and with gladness before God, according to the generations for ever among his people.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes the perpetual celebration of Purim, a lasting reminder of God’s salvation.
